Whether or not dogs do commit suicide still comes up for debate, most recently in Italy, for example. One bridge in west Scotland is known as “The Dog Suicide Bridge,” for being the scene, since the 1950s, of at least fifty dogs’ deaths. The “scientific” explanation, however, is that the dogs are so excited by the smell of mink musk that they leap over the parapet, without realizing the fifty foot drop beyond. Cold comfort. For more, see “Do Dogs Commit Suicide?”.
This was not dissimilar from what American defenders of the war in Cuba most valued in the U.S. occupation of the island—the seemingly humanitarian instinct that justified it.
Edward Jesse, Anecdotes of Dogs (London: Henry G. Bohn, 1858), p. 145.
Sarah Knowles Bolton, Our Devoted Friend, The Dog (Boston: L.C. Page and Co., 1902), 195. Bolton cites the New York World of May 30, 1899 for this anecdote.
